conversations.content: The Mercenary Prince: Part One
Roc flew through the sky, her injured master on her back. She had been watching over him since he was young, and never considered that he might one day die.
Known as the Mercenary Prince, he was in reality a mere nephew of the king of Alberia, and had little hope of actually claiming the throne.
But the blood of King Alberius was strong in him, and upon coming of age, he successfully formed a pact with a dragon, swearing to be together for as long as they lived.
With no lands to inherit, he chose instead to battle fiends, and spent his life wandering South Grastaea ever in search of combat.
To the people on the furthest reaches of the land, constantly threatened by fiends and unable to depend on the capital's aid, he was a blessing—and it was they who gave him his name.
Eventually, people began to wish that he would become the next king—a thought that was unsurprisingly not received well by the current regent.
The royal family accused the prince of working with fiends to seize the throne, and after securing permission from the Church to excommunicate him, they sent an army after him.
Thus was the prince forced to fight his own family. And with several dragons on their side, it did not take long for the royal family to secure victory.
The prince's death came from an arrow to the chest—an anticlimactic end if ever there was one. All who saw the impact knew instantly that it would be fatal.
Seizing their chance, the army moved in on the dying prince—but Roc gave a great roar and protected him with her wings.
After softly kissing him, she took him onto her back and soared into the air as the powerless army watched from afar.
That was the last glimpse mankind had of the prince, and none know what happened in his final moments. None, that is, save his lifelong companion.
The Mercenary Prince: Part Two
The veteran warrior of a dragon flew through the air, the dying prince on her back. All was silence, for they had left the hue and cry of battle far behind them.
Suddenly, the Mercenary Prince spoke Roc's name from her back. But the voice was weak, and she knew well that he would not last much longer.
＂I'm taking you to see Phoenix,＂ said the dragon. ＂A wound like this will be nothing to her—and if she refuses to help you, she'll have my claws in her neck.＂
＂It's fine,＂ said the prince weakly. ＂Dying in a warm bed ain't really for me, anyway. I've got no regrets about how I lived and...I loved fighting with you.＂
＂I'm just sorry I couldn't honor the promise that we made when we first formed our pact...＂
＂I dreamed of seeing peace brought to the continent...but it wasn't to be. No matter how much blood we shed, the end never came...＂
＂But even if I die, I'm sure that peace will one day come...and I want you to see it for me. I mean...you're gonna live forever...right...?＂
With that, the man breathed no more, and Roc let out a great wail of despair. The people below knew a great hero had left the world, and began to offer prayers for his soul.
Now, the Mercenary Prince is all but forgotten, and the royals who fought him confined to history books—but the peace he sought has not come to pass. How futile human dreams are!
But to such thoughts, Roc would only say, ＂It's not over so long as I live. I'll make his dream come true yet.＂
Those who seek the peace of the continent would do well to visit her. She is, after all, a mercenary—and if you share the dream of her former master, she will surely help you.
